A piece of arabyan craftsmanship that provides solid defense balanced with extreme lightness.
A tremendously ornamented piece, showing the value and rank of the lucky one who wears it.
No one knows the origin of this strange artifact, but it seems to ward off all magical power that is thrown at its bearer.
This armor was created by an ancient caliph to combat the threat of a cabal of bloody vampires.

Legends tell that an arabyan princess went deep into the desert in search of her brother. The fierce girl returned wearing a shining armor, snatched from an ancient Tomb King, and no one ever knew what had happened on her travels.
Uzzal, the arabyan goddess of protection, created this armor in ancient times, to fight the dreaded demons. Ensures the health of its bearer against any monster.
This magical armor protects its wearer from the punishment of the sun, while healing their wounds. It was forged in the ancient city of Dakisir, before its destruction by the Undead.

In the Gorgon Shield, the image of a Gorgon is displayed, a horrible creature said to inhabit the deserts of Araby. It is rumored that if an enemy looks into the eyes of the face painted on the shield, it will turn to stone. This has never happened in recent memory, but the reputation of the shield is great enough that adversaries put themselves at a disadvantage by trying to avoid the Gorgon Shield gaze.

A long-forgotten smith, unswerving in his faith, created this shield. It was once held by the hero Amir Bakir who was slain as he bravely charged into an overwhelming number of enemies during the Crusades. The shield is imbued with the power of the divine and may destroy any weapon that touches it.

This armour gives the wearer the abilities of a scorpion. It was last worn by Atabeg Zankhri, who travelled from the centre of the desert after a failed assassination attempt which resulted in the deaths of all his companions. He made it back to Khalibon, only to remove his armour and become the victim of a final dagger thrust by a shadowy assailant.

This armour was given as a present by the Dwarf Lord Khrumak to the Sultan Nur Al-Zangi. The armour was a reward to the Sultan for saving his caravan from a legion of undead that rose against him as he traversed the desert. It is covered in runes that grant supreme resistance to spells.
Worn by Sultans past, this gilded ruby encrusted armour while impractical, shows the wealth and power of it's wearer and thier power hungry ways.
The skill of the Arabyan warriors is unmatched as long as they guard the nimble and sharp scimitars of their homeland.
A sharp blade hidden in the assassin’s bracer, ideal for cutting the enemies’ throats.
Bearing the blessing of the Monarch of the Sea, goddess of protection for the Arabyan sailors, this scimitar will wipe out any threat before the enemy can react.
A weapon without equal, that only the fierce and strong inhabitants of the dunes are capable of handling correctly.

Given as a gift to an imperial mercenary for his displays of courage during the Siege of Sudenburg against the Undead, this scimitar was forged by the famed Arabyan philosopher and craftsman Hataq al-Kundi at the time of the Crusade.
This dagger was found clutched in a skeletal hand and buried under a mass of bodies. The wielder of the dagger sold his life dearly.
Forged from the best steel of all Araby, this scimitar encapsulates the skill of the best master craftsmen in the city of Dimashque.

Forged by Alik the Fanatic, the Martyr’s Shard gained its power as Alik lay dying, still clutching it to his bleeding chest. His readiness to give his life to his cause infused the dagger with divine power. The dagger now allows its wielder to strike horrifying wounds, if they are prepared to offer their lives in the process.

Bow of Seeking: This bow was a gift to Princess Shah’Razad from the Elven merchants that frequent Araby as a gift for her enchanting story-telling. Made from hardest ebony, this magical bow has been the death of many monsters in Araby. Any arrow shot using this magic bow will pursue the target and hit it even if it is behind cover.
This is a famed weapon that was wielded by Abakukh the Mighty. His lust for battle was such that he was overcome by the sword after slaying every enemy that stood against him on that fateful day.

This is one of the sword’s forged by Maha Zorouzahan that is imbued with spells from the magi of the Land of a Thousand Gods. When the word’s of power are uttered, the sword bursts into flame and grants its wielder immense power.
An old blade that still oozes a strange noxious liquid, a gift from shameful times where the Ratkin were once called allies.
Representing one of the fierce gods of Araby, this statue contains the will of the spirits.
Utilizing the power of arabyan wizards, this Abacus anticipates change, warning of future threats.
With the poison of the Tomb Beetle, a powerful Pendulum is created to chase nearby vampires, widely used by the caliphs of Araby.
This ancient Astrolabe was created by astrologer/engineer Asthra the Magian. It uses sorcery and knowledge of the heavens to point the holder in the direction of what she desires most.
A power without equal creeps among the rubies of this crown, because anyone who carries it will be able to bend the wills of many around him.

The ring is an heirloom from a line of great warriors who fought for your faith. The finger that wore it was severed during battle, resulting in the warrior’s demise. The ring has the power to mend the worst damage, even otherwise fatal wounds.
Crafted with elemental sorcery, this golden ring has a Djinn bound to it. The bearer can summon the Djinn who will protect its master.

The origins of this enigmatic relic has been lost over the centuries, suffice to say that it is extremely old and very valuable. It was used by the Caliph Ibn Rashid, in his wars against the undead hordes of King Khasetratepp. The wearer of the Mask projects an aura of holiness that the undead will shy away from.

Holy Scriptures of Mullah Aklan’d: The legendary Mullah Aklan’d was the most renowned legend in the entire history of Araby, and his everlasting fight against the High Elves has been set on fire in the hearts of the Arabyans. The self-proclaimed first Grand Sultan decided to write his memoirs, secrets and teachings in the so-called Holy Scriptures.
An old necklace whose pendant bears a strange triangle, it is said it will call out to burrowing beasts to this day, a gift from shameful times where the Ratkin were once called allies.

The master explorer made use of this magical compass that always marks a true path and wards it's bearer from dangerous lands. It's orign is unknown, some say it was crafted by Ibn's own hand, others a lizardmen trinket batered for in the Southlands.

Created from a series of enchanted mirrors by the mad wizard Mahik Al'Rak, this small shard accidentally broke away after Imperial and Bretonnian crusaders stormed the tower, to gaze upon it is to gaze upon Chaos.
With a pinch of the energy from the sun inside, this device is made by the most expert alchemists of Araby.
Obtained from the deep ruined chambers of the cursed Nehekhara, this relic contains a power long forgotten.

Cheshnakk was a great wizard from Araby whose celebrated skill led to the creation of the most exquisite flying carpets. The problem of his achievements, however, was the forging of the Cheshnakk Ring. In all its power, this ring can transport its wearer back to his home.
Concentrating the power of the gods of Araby, the power that hides this artifact returns to its controller as silent as the same night.

Ishmail, the god of Araby related to night, secrets and stars, hides secrets from ages past. After creating the Djinns, this powerful deity left powerful artifacts in the mortal world, with supreme abilities that few can understand.
A toy from a bygone era, it tells of a tale of deception that brought the fall of a great city.
It is said to smoke from this pipe brings great clarity & calm. Many strange deals and allies have emerged from inhaling it's intoxicating fumes.
Hailing from the land of a thousand gods, magic ropes have allowed many thiefs to perform extraordinary feats.
When filled with water and the sacred rites incited it is said that any object that touches the now divine water is impervious to magic.
The powerful arabyan sorceress known as Laniph created strange artifacts to contain the Winds of Magic inside it.
A strange object that allows its wielder to manipulate the Winds of Magic to appease, something unpredictable in distant Araby.
The Whirlpool Staff is inscribed with esoteric calligraphy that teaches the wielder how to intercept hostile magic and dispel it.

Carved from the petrified prob of ancient, wind blasted prob, the Sandstorm Staff contains the very essence of the desert. With the help of the elves, the greatest Arabyan elementalists bound the power of the desert into these staffs, which were once thought lost to the sands.
The last writing of the arabyan necromancer Harak-Iman, it remain as a vestige of this dark art among the dunes, hidden in the distant city of Ma’arra.

Scattered across the lands of Araby are the pages of the Book of the Dead, written by the mad Arabyan, Abdul Alhazred. The forbidden lore on the pages will instill in the reader vast knowledge in the ways of death and the afterlife.

This strange and disgusting object is used mainly during the strange religious rites of the nomadic tribes of the Tuareg and has a similar power to the Magic Lamps. As with the powers of the fickle Djinns, the Monkey Paw is not always beneficial to its owner. Every time its owner makes a wish, a toe will snap shut, making it come true. But the way to fulfill the wishes is extremely twisted, always implying the torment of its owner.
Created by potent magic and modelled on it's very real forebearer, this one is made from glass, it blinds all around when the sun strikes it, it is as hard as it is fragile.
Dulled by time, this bronze work is nearly unbreakable but it's weight is unbearable.

It is said to have been a gift from the Monkey King to the far east in Cathay to celebrate the advent of trading relations thought others say it it is a cursed gift revenge for Cathay's failed invasion of the Southlands.

This finely crafted piece of jewelry is home to a benevolent Genie. He act as guardian to his master and can offer helpful advice with his powers of insight. However, his overwhelming power can become a problem.
Not all genies make home in lavish ornaments or wish to be disturbed. some prefer to stay hidden in plain sight.
